questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding all over the world is senile endometrial 
atrophy. In a menopausal woman, hypoestrogenism causes atrophy of the endometrium and vagina.The 
atrophic endometrial surfaces contain little or no fluid to prevent intracavitary friction. This 855 
Sold by @itachibot results in micro-erosions of the surface epithelium and a subsequent chronic inflammatory 
reaction, making the endometrium prone to light bleeding or spotting. Hormone replacement therapy is the second most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding all 
over the world. Cervical cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in India, while 
endometrial cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in developed 
countries. Note: Endometrial cancer accounts for only 10 % of cases of post-menopausal bleeding. Still, all 
postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial 
carcinoma, since this is a potentially lethal disease.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 58-year-old, postmenopausal woman presented with bleeding PV. Hysteroscopic biopsy 
revealed complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the risk of progression of this 
condition to cancer?
questions.explanation:
Complex hyperplasia with atypia has a 29% increased risk of progression to endometrial cancer. It 
has the highest risk of progressing to carcinoma compared to other varieties of endometrial 
hyperplasia. The risk of endometrial hyperplasia progressing to cancer is tabulated below. Type of hyperplasia 
Progression to cance 
r Simple without atypia 
1% 3% Complex without atyp 
ia Simple with atypia 
8% Complex with atypia 
29%

questions.question: Question 3: Which is the most common benign cause of pyometra?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of pyometra is senile endometritis. Pyometra refers the collection of pus in the uterus. The most common cancer that causes 
pyometra is carcinoma cervix followed by carcinoma endometrium.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple 
hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia?
questions.explanation:
Simple hysterectomy is the best treatment in a case of atypical endometrial hyperplasia in a 
peri-menopausal and post-menopausal female. Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia carries 29% risk of developing into endometrial carcinoma 
and hence, must be treated with total abdominal hysterectomy (simple hysterectomy ). 856 
Sold by @itachibot The presence of any concomitant endometrial cancer must be ruled out by doing fractional 
curettage (or dilatation and curettage) before doing a hysterectomy. If a premenopausal woman does not desire to undergo hysterectomy, progesterone can be given 
and the patient is followed up every 3-6 months. If the atypia persists during the follow-up 
hysterectomy should be performed. The table below summarizes the management of patients with endometrial hyperplasia Management of Endometrial 
hyperplasia Hyperplasia without atypia Pre-menopausal women

questions.question:
Question 5: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which 
you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.explanation:
A finding of endometrial thickness  4 mm (according to ACOG) in a postmenopausal 
women requires further evaluation, such as endometrial biopsy. If the endometrial thickness is 4 mm in a post menopausal female, malignancy is rare and hence, 
can be managed by tranexamic acid. If the bleeding still persists, the patient needs to undergo 
fractional curettage and hysteroscopy. The algorithm for next step for abnormal uterine bleeding in different age groups is as follows: Action Age group

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common histopathological variety of endometrial cancer?
questions.explanation:
The most common variety of endometrial cancer is adenocarcinoma. The other varieties of endometrial cancer are squamous cell, clear cell, and serous. The most 
malignant varieties are clear cell carcinoma and papillary serous tumor.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following predisposes a patient to develop type 2 carcinoma endometrium?
questions.explanation:
Type 2 carcinoma endometrium is commonly seen in menopausal women with atrophic 
endometrium. Histological classification of endometrial cancer: Note: Type 1 (estrogen-dependent) endometrial CA is the more common type. Type 1 (Endometrioid)

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following constitute corpus cancer syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Corpus cancer syndrome constitutes of: • Diabetes mellitus • Obesity • Hypertension • Cancer of the body of the uterus. Etiology of endometrial carcinoma: (Mnemonic: Family Has OLD AUNTI) • Family history • Hypertension • Obesity • Late menopause/Early menarche • Diabetes • Atypical endometrial hyperplasia • Unopposed estrogen/increased estrogen  Hormone replacement therapy, fibroid, PCOD • Nulliparous • Tamoxifen therapy (Raloxifene has no genito-urinary action) • Infertility/irregular menses. Protective factors against endometrial carcinoma include the use of OCPs, smoking, and 
multiparity.

questions.question:
Question 9: A gynecologist is performing the following procedure in a woman with postmenopausal 
bleeding. Identify it.
questions.explanation:
The image depicts saline infusion sonography (SIS), also known as sonohysterography. It is 
usually done after a transvaginal ultrasound, to assess the detailed anatomy of the uterine cavity. In this procedure, a balloon catheter is inserted through the cervix and the endometrial cavity is 
distended with 20-40ml of sterile saline. The balloon is inflated to block the backflow of the 
infused sterile saline and transvaginal ultrasound is performed to visualize the cavity. It is used: 859 
Sold by @itachibot • To determine the endometrial thickness • To determine the cause in cases of infertility • To identify Mullerian anomalies • To visualize endometrial polyps and pedunculated fibroids The image given below shows the appearance of the uterus on SIS. Option A: Transvaginal ultrasound is the initial evaluation for postmenopausal bleeding. Option B: In balloon endometrial ablation, a balloon is inserted into the uterus and inflated with 
glycine or 5% glucose. It is then heated up, and the endometrium is ablated by the tamponade 
effect. Option D: In hysterosalpingography, contrast dye is inserted into the uterus via a catheter, and 
the uterine and fallopian tube anatomy is visualized.

questions.question:
Question 10: A menopausal patient suspected to have endometrial carcinoma is undergoing a transvaginal 
ultrasound. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Decreased vascular resistance with increased tumor vascularity is seen in carcinoma 
endometrium. USG findings in carcinoma endometrium include: • Endometrial thickness >4 mm in postmenopausal women and >10 mm in perimenopausal 
women • Hyperechoic endometrium with irregular outlines • Increased tumor vascularity with low vascular resistance • Fluid in uterine cavity 860 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 52-year-old■ woman with postmenopausal bleeding has an endometrial thickness of 7 mm 
on ultrasound. What is the next step in her management?
questions.explanation:
The next line of management in a patient with increased endometrial thickness is an endometrial 
biopsy. In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness. If it 
exceeds 4 mm, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory, 
irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms. In a perimenopausal woman, the cutoff for 
normal endometrial thickness is 10mm. Hysteroscopy and biopsy is preferred over other blind curettage methods for HPE. A biopsy is 
made from suspicious areas after visualization so chances of missing the lesion are reduced.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 54-year-old woman with postmenopausal bleeding is suspected to have an endometrial 
lesion. What is the gold standard investigation to confirm her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy is now considered the gold standard in the 
diagnosis of an endometrial lesion. It is preferred for the initial evaluation of women with 
bleeding suspicious for malignancy. Endometrial sampling can be done by hysteroscopic biopsy. It is more sensitive for focal 
endometrial lesions. Dilatation and curettage may also aid the sampling of endometrial lesions. Ultrasound, CT, and MRI are adjuvant to other investigations. Diagnostic laparoscopy will be 
required to study the nature of the tumor and its spread if ultrasound picks up a pelvic tumor. The image given below shows the procedure of hysteroscopy.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 62-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding 11 years after she had attained 
menopause. An endometrial biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma. What is the gold standard 
method for staging her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario depicts endometrial carcinoma and the gold standard method for staging this 
condition is surgery. 861 
Sold by @itachibot According to FIGO/TNM classification system, a total hysterectomy with bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy and pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection is the standard staging 
procedure for endometrial cancer. Option A: Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) appears to be the best 
radiographic modality for detecting myometrial invasion or cervical involvement. Option C: Hysteroscopy visualizes the entire uterine lining and a biopsy is taken from suspicious 
areas. This is not 100% predictive, as an early lesion can be missed. Recently, the concern has 
been raised regarding the spilling of cancer cells into the peritoneal cavity during hysteroscopy. Option D: PET–CT reveals metabolic activity in the tissue and is highly sensitive and specific for 
detecting positive pelvic and/or para-aortic lymphadenopathy as well as distant metastases in 
selected high-risk patients with endometrial cancer.

questions.question: Question 14: Which lymph nodes are most commonly involved in patients with endometrial carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are commonly involved in endometrial cancer. The spread is through the infundibulopelvic ligament. Rarely, inguinal & femoral lymph nodes are involved.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient presented with carcinoma endometrium involving >50% myometrium, extending 
to the vagina but with no involvement of para-aortic and pre aortic nodes. What is the stage 
of her disease?
questions.explanation:
Carcinoma endometrium involving the vagina but having no lymph node involvement is classified 
as stage IIIB.

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is indicated for the treatment of a patient with early endometrial 
cancer?

options.a: Hysterectomy, B/L salpingo-oophorectomy, lymph node sampling

questions.explanation:
Early endometrial cancer (stages I & II) is primarily managed surgically. The surgery 
performed here is abdominal hysterectomy, B/L salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy and pelvic 
& para-aortic lymph node sampling. Postoperative management of endometrial cancer: In low-risk endometrial cancer, no further treatment is required. In intermediate-risk, radiotherapy is done. In high risk, chemotherapy + radiotherapy is done.

questions.question:
Question 17: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is 
true?

options.a: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
options.b: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
options.c: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.explanation:
The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance. This is known as the 
inverse square law in radiotherapy. 862 
Sold by @itachibot Chemoradiation is the mainstay of treatment of stage III and IV endometrial cancers. They are 
treated with brachytherapy followed by external radiation. Brachytherapy is a form of radiation 
therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. Other options: Option B: Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature. Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells. Option D: Small intestinal epithelial cells (intestinal crypts), which divide rapidly with no 
differentiation are the most radiosensitive.

questions.question:
Question 18: Which among the following is the mainstay of treatment in a patient diagnosed with Stage III 
endometrial cancer? 854 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment in Stage III endometrial cancer. In order to stage carcinoma endometrium, total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy and lymphadenectomy is done (surgical staging). Thus the management, once staging is done, is mainly postoperative. Up to stage II, radiotherapy 
can be given. Stages III & IV are managed by chemotherapy such as doxorubicin, 
cisplatin, and paclitaxel. Note: Stage III is said to be inoperable but debulking surgery is sometimes attempted. However, 
the mainstay of treatment for stage III disease remains chemotherapy. 863 
Sold by @itachibot Instruments
